article:
The term 'Muslim world' (also known as the 'Ummah' For the definition, see:
. or 'Islamosphere' Amir Ahmad Nasr. My Isl@m: How Fundamentalism
Stole My Mind --- and Doubt Freed My Soul. Page 147. 2013. James
Bowman. Honor: A History. Page 26. 2007. ) has several meanings. In a
religious sense, the Islamic Ummah refers to those who adhere to the teachings
of Islam, referred to as Muslims. In a cultural sense, the Muslim Ummah refers
to Islamic civilization, inclusive of non-Muslims living in that civilization.
In a modern geopolitical sense, the term Islamic Nation usually refers
collectively to Muslim-majority countries, states, districts, or towns.
[[File:Islam by country.png|thumb|500px|Countries with more than 5% Muslim
population. Source for distribution is the CIA World Factbook,
Shiite/Sunnite distribution collected from other sources. Shiites may be
underrepresented in some countries where they do not appear in official
statistics. Sunni Shias Ibadi]] Although, Islamic lifestyles emphasise
unity and defence of fellow Muslims, schools and branches (see Shi'aâSunni
relations, for example) exist. In the past both Pan-Islamism and nationalist
currents have influenced the status of the Muslim world.

As of 2010, over 1.6 billion or about 23.4% of the world population are Muslims. Of these, around 62% live in Asia-Pacific, 20% in the Middle East-North Africa, 15% in Sub-Saharan Africa, around
3% in Europe and 0.3% in the Americas.
